Award.AwardTitle: Electronic, Magnetic, and Spectroscopic Properties of Molecular Solids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical abstract

This research addresses molecular materials, an area of emerging importance. These materials, which are carbon based and often called "organic", are beginning to complement, or even replace materials such as copper, silicon, and others that have been the mainstay of technology. Research questions and investigations involve how electrical conductivity, magnetism, and superconductivity arise and behave in molecular materials, and how to modify the materials to exploit desirable new properties. Diverse methods are employed, including high pressure, high magnetic field, and low temperature environments, in conjunction with electrical, magnetic, and spectroscopic (optical, x-ray, magnetic resonant) probes. The award mainly supports graduate students. Their work and training is interdisciplinary, and designed to prepare them to solve problems in a competitive global environment. Each student interacts with scientists outside their immediate area, including chemists (who provide many materials) and engineers (who have advanced methods of characterization and the culture of finding relevance to applications). Through interactions with National Laboratories and NSF-supported international programs, students are exposed to many different areas of materials research, often collaborating with world-class experts. Likewise, students play active mentorship roles in middle school, high school, REU, RET, senior thesis, and other training programs.

Technical abstract

This award addresses the nature and interaction of spin, charge and lattice degrees of freedom in anisotropic (low-dimensional) materials generally described as organic conductors or superconductors, molecular conductors or magnets. The approach is experimental, utilizing transport, structural, spectroscopic, thermodynamic, optical, and resonant probes. Although the work is fundamental in scope, the understanding and control of electronic charge (conduction) by spin (magnetism), and vice versa, on the molecular level is an important goal in many fields of science. A main theme of the project is the comparative behavior of isostructural materials where only the localized d-electron spin at one lattice site, or more generally, in one molecular chain or plane, can be turned on or off by chemical alloying. Questions to be answered include: How do the d-electron spins and the pi-electron spins order magnetically? How do they interact? What is the role of the lattice in these interactions? Can charge and spin be controlled by external parameters? The highly interdisciplinary nature of molecular materials provides an excellent venue for wide collaborations and international experiences for young researchers in degree programs. This theme, with a broad range of topics to choose from, offers simple bench-top projects that draw young researchers at the pre-degree level to the lab to test and develop their scientific interests and skills

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: Electronic, Magnetic, and Spectroscopic properties of Molecular Solids
Project #: NSF-DMR- I 005293

The objective of this proposal was to address electronic, magnetic, and spectroscopic properties of molecular solids. In molecular solids, molecules can be viewed as individual atoms in inorganic solids, therefore their physical properties are determined by the molecular level. The nature and interaction of spin, charge, and lattice degree of freedom in molecular solids lead to diverse physical properties including superconductivity, magnetism, metal-insulator transition, and so forth. 

Our experimental approach was to utilize many traditional and advanced methods to investigate the diverse physical properties of molecular solids. One example of such approach can be found in our published works on low dimensional molecular crystal Per2[Pt(mnt)2], where Per and mnt stand for perylene and maleonitriledithiolate molecules, respectively.  This material consists of two chains; conducting perylene chains and insulating spin [Pt(mnt)2] chains. We performed proton NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance) and TDO (Tunnel Diode Oscillator) measurements at low temperatures and high fields up to 45 Tesla. From these studies, we found persistent interactions between the two chains at high magnetic fields in contrast to a simple theoretical model and a new spin-gapped phase appearing in the field-induced insulating phase. Along with our previous magnetic torque and magneto-transport studies, the new findings provide fresh insights into the nature of the field-induced phase and magnetic properties of the dual-chain spin and charge system.

One aspect of the project is to stimulate international collaborations and to host talented young researchers to visit our group for participating in the project. Through this effort, a few exemplary works has been done, such as high field magneto-transport measurement under pressure on quasi-one-dimensional molecular crystals (DIETSe)2FeBr4 and HMTSF-TCNQ and magneto-thermopower measurements on a quasi-two-dimensional organic conductor α-(BEDT-TTF)2KHg(SCN)4. In particular, the collaborations have led us to investigate a more complicated form of molecular solids, for example spider silk, which is a protein (a biomolecule) based, non-crystalline molecular solid.

 The synergetic approach of utilizing various experimental tools on molecular solids was found to be useful in exploring the multifunctional properties of silk materials. We investigated mechanical, surface, electronic, spectroscopic, and water diffusion properties of silk at various environments and discovered its unique physical properties and possible applications as a hybrid material with other inoganic/inorganic solids.

 The scope of this project was mainly related to the fundamental understanding of molecular solids and many achievements were accomplished within the scope, producing a number of publications. The methodology and knowledge we learned through this project are expected to serve as a stepping stone for further investigation on molecular solids relevant to materials research.
